Award.AwardTitle: Low-Dimensional Topology via Bordered Floer Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project in low-dimensional topology investigates the global shape of various three-dimensional spaces and of knotted curves and surfaces within them. Since the space we inhabit is three-dimensional, this field has wide-ranging applications, from understanding the possible shapes of the universe to describing the knotting of polymers and DNA molecules. Understanding the properties of three-dimensional spaces requires an array of sophisticated tools from a range of disciplines within mathematics, including algebraic topology, geometry, analysis, and representation theory. Each tool for studying three-dimensional spaces carries with it a notion of which spaces are "simple" and which are "complicated." The primary goal of this project is to explore the relationship between different tools used to describe three-dimensional spaces and the corresponding notions of simplicity. Ultimately the investigator hopes to consolidate and deepen our knowledge of these spaces and to build bridges between a variety of mathematical fields.

A key technical tool to be used in this investigation is bordered Heegaard Floer homology, a version of Heegaard Floer homology for 3-manifolds with boundary. In particular, the project centers on developing a new geometric interpretation of bordered Heegaard Floer invariants; this is a concrete realization of a deep connection between bordered Heegaard Floer homology and certain Fukaya categories. In the case of torus boundary, the invariants may be interpreted as decorated immersed curves in the boundary torus. This framework greatly simplifies computations and leads to proofs of interesting gluing results. This will be applied to the classification of L-spaces (3-manifolds that are "simple" with respect to Heegaard Floer homology). As one application, the investigator seeks to confirm a conjecture equating three measures of simplicity for 3-manifolds: being an L-space, having non-left-orderable fundamental group, and not admitting a co-orientable taut foliation. Other goals of the project include restricting the possible decompositions of L-space knots and relating Heegaard Floer homology to the complexity of the Jaco-Shalen-Johannson decomposition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated knots and 3-dimensional manifolds, two basic objects in low-dimensional topology, using a family of invariants known as Heegaard Floer homology. In particular, the project sought to better understand Heegaard Floer invariants for 3-manifolds with boundary, such as the complement of a knot in 3-dimensional space. Such invariants, called bordered Heegaard Floer homology, were previously defined by Lipshitz, Ozsvath, and Szabo, but the resulting algebraically complex objects are rather difficult to work with. The first fundamental outcome of this project was to show that bordered Heegaard Floer invariants can be reinterpreted in a graphical way. For a knot complement or any other 3-manifold with torus boundary, all the information captured by Heegaard Floer homology can be encoded in a simple picture, namely in a curve or collection of curves drawn on a lattice in the plane (see Figure). Several important properties of the 3-manifold or knot are encoded by geometeric properties of these curves such as the maximum and minimum height and the range of tangent slopes it has.

This new geometric interpretation of Heegaard Floer invariants makes them a more useful tool, and this project also produced several applications to open problems in low-dimensional topology. We highlight two of these below.

 

L-space classification:

An 3-manifold whose Heegaard Floer homology is as simple as possible is called an L-space. This is one reasonable notion of what it means for a manifold to be "simple", so classifying which manifolds are L-spaces is an important goal in the field. One major open conjecture, known as the L-space conjecture, states that this notion of simplicity for 3-manifolds is equivalent to another notion of simplicity coming from a property of the fundamental group, as well as to another notion of simplicity using the geometry of foliations.

One of the key applications coming from this project was a gluing formula which says exactly when gluing two manifolds with torus boundary together produces an L-space. The condition has to do with the slopes realized by the two sets of curves and has a surprsingly simple geometric proof. This generalized an earlier result which proved the gluing condition held in certain special cases. That earlier result had been used to prove that the L-space conjecture is true for a large class of 3-manifolds called graph manifolds.

 

Cosmetic surgery conjecture:

Removing a knot from a 3-manifold and gluing it back in a different way produces a new 3-manifold. This procedure is called Dehn surgery, and through it knots can be viewed as the basic building blocks of 3-manifolds. All closed 3-manifolds can be constructed from the simplest 3-manifold (the 3-dimensional sphere) by doing surgery on knots. Despite this, much remains unknown about the surgery operation. For instance, one can ask how many differnt ways a given manifold can be obtained through surgery. Along these lines, the Cosmetic Surgery Conjecture asserts that if one does two different surgeries on the same knot in the 3-sphere, the resulting 3-manifolds must be different.

The methods developed in this project lead to the most substantial progress on this conjecture in 10 years. While the conjecture remains open, the we proved that it is true in most cases. Here in "most cases" means unless the knot has Heegaard Floer homology satisfying a very particular property, something true of only about 300 of the first 1.7 million knots. Moreover, even for these knots, we show at most two pairs of surgery exist which might the same result. This allows the conjecture to be checked on these remaining knots by a (finite) computer computation of other invariants. In this way, the conjecture is now confirmed for the first 1.7 million knots (all prime knots with at most 16 crossings).

 

This project had a substantial impact on the field, both by making progress on important open problems and by providing a new tool for understanding Heegaard Floer invariants. The PI has shared this work at numerous conferences, including teaching a summer mini-course for graduate students on the new tools developed in this project. Already several exciting results have appeard from other mathematicians using these concepts, demonstrating how valuable these contributions are and will continue to be in broadening our understanding of low-dimensional topology.
